posts.cooked: My team is looking into switching our can from a daisy-chained can to a can bus topology. Where we have a main line and then branch off of it to motors or groups of motors. What tips or suggestions do you have for this?  What rules are you supposed to follow when doing can bus?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Technically a daisy-chain IS a CANbus topology. What youre describing is a star topology, which is also a CANbus topology

CANbus isnt really intended to work that way (at least not how it’s implemented in FRC), but thats not to say it can’t work.  Youll want to keep all of your branches as short as possible (under 12" segments, but shorter is better), and I believe you’ll need terminating resistors for each.

I’m sure others will have better advice though. I’ve never done this myself, but I’ve seen teams at events that have

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
Just one terminating resistor, can still be power panel.

And obviously don’t short the bus at the unterminated ends.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Thanks for the correction. I was thinking it was needed for each branch off of the main bus, but I guess not.  I know it’s needed for both ends of the main bus (most commonly provided by Rio and PDP/PDH)

reply_to_user.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.cooked: The benefits of doing a star are amazing, my team wanted to try that unfortunately we couldn’t test it soon enough this year. Maybe next year. The big thing to look out for is wire length and ensure that your routing has a clear start and end. Remember ONLY ONE of the two CAN pairs from motor controllers like SparkMax’s or TalonFX’s should be connected in a star topology, NEVER BOTH. If your wire length (which is the total length of all wire on your bus even the unconnected ones) gets too high you will see some degradation.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: Ideally you want to put the other terminator (one is in the RIO, you need 2 total) at the farthest point electrically from the RIO.  Realistically you just need to have a 2nd terminator somewhere. All this applies to CAN.  If you’re using CAN FD (you have a CANivore and a bunch of Falcons) you must pay very close attention to bus topology.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
We have made robots, competition and test, with any manor of horrible mish-mashed topos: star, daisy chain, and unbalanced multi-link star (e.g. 1-3 SparkMAXes per leg of the star topo. We have never detected an issue with any of these.

We used a termination resistor in the center of the star when going that route.

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked:
I wanted to groan about someone opening this can of worms again, then I realized it would sound like a bad pun.

This is a topic that (in prior CD threads) somehow tends to generate a lot more controversy than it should. I will do my best to provide as straight-forward an explanation as possible.

A CAN Bus is just a network bus set up for CAN protocol. A network bus is a network topology in which nodes (devices) all are connected to a common trunk that runs the length of the network. A CAN Bus’ topology should essentially look like this:

FRC COTS electronics designed to interface with the CAN Bus have adopted a number of different features, presumably intended to lower the barrier to entry for CAN implementation (some more successfully than others). Among those are the integration of 120Ohm resistors into the roboRio and PDP/PDH (which allows for teams to not have to install an additional terminating resistor if using these on either end of their bus), and the usage of electrical passthrus on CAN connections on the PCB of speed controllers to allow for the daisy chaining of devices.

To be clear, daisy-chained devices from CTRE, Rev, NI, etc. are still in a Bus. The H and L circuits are continuous, with the PCBs in these speed controllers acting as the stubs of the bus to each node.

However, many teams and individuals (including myself) do not like having multiple connections along the trunk of the bus, as the daisy chain implementation creates. If one of those connections fails, you lose all the devices (and the 120Ohm terminating resistor) after the failure. This is opposed to if a single node’s connection were to fail in a more traditional bus wiring implementation, in which just that node would lose connection. Additionally, this requires the trunk of your bus to end up on any exposed position of a ESC on your robot, which increases risk. As a result, teams have looked for alternative implementations to wire their CAN bus.

When you hear people discussing a “Star Topology,” what they’re really discussing is still a Bus, but with the central Bus trunk in the form of a busbar (or similar). In essence, they’re reducing length of the bus to a minimum, and eliminating connections along the length of the trunk of the bus. So long as each stub is short (<12"), this is still in accordance with the ISO spec’s recommendations for a CAN Bus.

There are other methods, as well. My preferred solution is to use wire taps along a CAN bus trunk to branch the stubs off. This allows for the trunk to be routed around your robot as appropriate to help minimize stub length, but still allowing the flexibility to have some stub length to protect the trunk of the bus (you don’t have to route it onto a turret or manipulator to facilitate a speed controller on those devices). Once again, so long as you keep the stub lengths <12", it meets ISO specifications for CAN Bus.

Both the “star topology” (bus bar) and wire taps have been used successfully by teams in FRC for multiple seasons.

What is not within ISO specification, and may or may not create issues, is having multiple branches off a shared stub (snowflake, tree, or hybrid topologies ). Additionally, stubs >12" may or may not cause message collisions.

(edit - corrected wire tap link)

posts.name: Justin
posts.cooked:
As someone who works in vehicle system engineering, CAN networks flip the excitement trigger in my brain, and I just want to emphasize my endorsement of what you’re saying here.

As an additional note, CAN networks are robust to a fault. I’ve seen CAN busses without one of the termination resistors working, I’ve seen some very NOT suggested layouts working.

Thankfully for FIRST teams, the barrier to entry is very low. FIRST takes care of a lot of the low level intricacies that need to be addressed, and all we have to do is make sure no 2 nodes share a source address. Because of this, there seems to be every year, a misunderstanding to what CAN is, and what it does. This is ok, as it’s an opportunity to learn.

Thanks for your detailed explanation. If anyone is looking for answers to their CAN questions, this is a good start.

posts.name: Siddharth Lohani
posts.cooked: My team uses these and they’ve worked very well for us so far. Tested at offseason comps this year and no issues. I love the convenience of adding new devices on the network and its additional fault tolerance.

You can also use these from playing with fusion.

posts.cooked: The Rio canbus is pretty forgiving. The Canivore bus which runs at a higher speed,is considerable less so. Just a point of information
